headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Interview With Lynda Carter; Interview With Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass. Aired 11:30a-12p ET

utterances.speaker: KATE BEDINGFIELD, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: I don't think I'm the solution here? How rare is that?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT JENNINGS, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Selfless, yes.

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: So I think that -- yes, so I think tonight that, yes, Kamala Harris will become the leader of the political Democratic Party, yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: You think he arrived at this decision that's delivering him into this stage on Monday night through some selfless introspection?

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: I think a lot of -- I...

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: And he wasn't strong-armed and bullied out of this race by the very people in this room tonight?I mean, look, he...

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, he didn't have to give it up. I mean, he..

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: That's the thing. I think a lot of elected officials have undergone...(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Maybe he did.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, Donald Trump did not ever concede the 2020 election. So, I mean, there is a slight difference there.

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: And you know what? Tonight, the Democrats are going to put on the stage some of the people involved in the January 6 investigation, the committee on Capitol Hill.That's another point of contrast that's going to raise a character question about Donald Trump. And, I mean, I do wonder, as a Republican, if you wish that more of your colleagues had strong-armed him into stepping aside.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Well, we had a real primary. I mean, the Republicans had a primary, where people showed up and they voted their preferences. And then the person they voted for actually got the nomination of the party.That's not what the Democrats did. They had a rigged primary, where 14 million people voted for Biden and then they changed their minds later. So if you want to talk about the party of democracy, I do wonder, I do wonder about the optics of the person who's going to get the nomination here has never gotten a single vote for this office. At least the Republicans had a vote and we stuck to it.

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: She was on the ticket with him that got 14 million votes in this primary.Also, the incumbent president running effectively more or less unopposed in the primary is pretty standard operating procedure. So to suggest now that that's some sort of undemocratic effort is just -- that's just not true. That's not true.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I mean, you had the guy resigned by tweet. I mean...

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, wait.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BEDINGFIELD
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, wait. So, wait, communicating by tweet is now no longer acceptable for presidential nominees? Because I think you guys might have a problem with that.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: You ran the president of the United States out of his -- he's been in this profession for 52 years, and you ran this man out of his job by tweet on a Sunday morning. I mean, it's pretty rough.I mean, look, my hat's off to you. You guys' party bosses, I get it. Like, you all are rough players.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: We are in Chicago, yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You know what?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is like -- I'm kind of in awe of it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Listen, we are in unprecedented times.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Kate and Scott, thank you both.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right, guys, thanks a lot. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: When we come...

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Scott had his coffee this week. He did.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: He sure -- he does every day, actually.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to this special edition of CNN NEWSROOM from the Democratic National Convention right here in Chicago. I'm Abby Phillip.And among the speakers at the convention this week are two former presidents, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton, and, of course, vice presidential nominee Tim Walz. A key ally of Vice President Kamala Harris is Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass. And she will help kick it off and address the delegates tonight 7:00 p.m. Eastern time. You can see the vice president there swearing her in back in 2022. Mayor Karen Bass joins me now. You all go way back. KAREN BASS (D), MAYOR OF LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA:  That's right.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All the way back.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I imagine you have probably spoken to her in the last couple of weeks...

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Oh, you know what?(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: ... a time or two.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: She has just been so busy, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: So, what would be your advice to her in this moment?Someone was reminding me that, four years ago, there was no real convention called, right?

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Right. That's right. That's right. We were all in COVID.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: This type of stage...

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: ... this type of room, even the audience is different. What's your advice to your friend?

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Well, let me just tell you, as I have watched her over the last two to three weeks, she is well-prepared for Thursday.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: The crowds that she has been dealing with now on the campaign trail have been the same size as this stadium.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: So I think she's going to do really well. I just think she should be natural, she should be fearless, and that is who she is and who she has been.And I think Thursday is going to be such an exciting evening.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: So, what are the things, though, of -- even though she is the sitting vice president, a lot of voters are telling pollsters they don't know what she stands for.What does she stand for?

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, first of all, as vice president, she has been key in terms of the Biden/Harris agenda.One of the things that comes to mind for me because of my background is health care, lowering the cost of prescription drugs. The cost of insulin, which was $100 or more, now is $35. Those are life-and-death issues for Americans. And so I think she has been very clear about what she stands for, the infrastructure bill, all that has been described. And now she's developing her own agenda, the economic agenda that she laid out the other day.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: So, I mean, there's a lot of policy that you have just mentioned there.And I think just reasonable, level-headed people this election should be about the issues that matter to people. But it's also going to be about a lot of personal attacks.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: You know, I think handling it with class, as she has been doing over the last couple of weeks, not taking the bait.But just think about it for a minute. He has no idea how to run against her. He doesn't know what to do. And when he doesn't know what to do, then he goes to the lowest common denominator, which is to attack her on race, on gender. And it just shows who he is.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Well, the former president and his running mate, J.D. Vance, are going to be giving some speeches this week counterprogramming on crime.You are the mayor of one of the big Democrat-led cities that they like to say are bad on the issue of crime. But, look, I like to say we can talk about the numbers. And I believe the numbers show a drop in crime pretty much across the board in this country.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But there are probably people feeling unsafe in this country, in the big cities and suburbs, whatever.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: What should the Democrat message be on that?

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, I think the Democrats need to be and have been clear about crime, which is, it is unacceptable. When it happens, it needs to be dealt with, and people need to be held accountable to the full extent of the law.But we also need a comprehensive approach, which means I want to do whatever I can to prevent crime. And so what this administration has done in terms of community violence prevention, the grants that have been issued to communities around the country, is also a key component. But we cannot equivocate when it comes to crime. Crime is a problem. It has been a problem in Los Angeles. The data shows that crime is going down. But when neighborhoods and individuals experience crime, we have to address it and we have to be aggressive.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Does she have an opportunity to be -- to lean into a part of her resume that might suggest a tough-on-crime approach as a former prosecutor?

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Well, you know what? I remember, when she was the DA and when I was speaker of the state Assembly, she was very clear about being smart on crime.That was the name of a book that she wrote.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Right. She kind of, I don't want to say coined, but she popularized that phrase, yes.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Right. Right. Right.But what she was saying in that phrase was, you have to address crime when it happens, but there are strategies to prevent crime. There are strategies to get young people away from gangs. And so having that comprehensive approach, I think, is absolutely critical. And the nerve of somebody who has faced as many indictments and convictions as Trump to then talk about the vice president in terms of crime is quite hypocritical.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You are -- we were talking in the break about the Olympics.First of all, you were in Paris to receive the Olympic torch from Paris. What was that moment like for you personally just to be there to experience that? And what are you looking forward to?

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Well, I will tell you, it was a surreal moment. It was an incredible honor to be on that international stage.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: They set a pretty high bar over in Paris, I have to say.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: They did. They did. It was wonderful.But, to me, the honor, aside from representing my city, state and country, was standing next to one of the greatest Olympians in history, Simone Biles. And it was just an honor to meet her and to share that moment with her.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, she is incredible.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: She absolutely is.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And I watched a lot of gymnastics with my 3-year-old, and she loved it. She loved it.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: She's -- she and Simone are on a first-name basis around my household.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: That's great.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass, thank you very much for joining us today.

utterances.speaker: BASS
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me on.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right, some big names in entertainment playing a big part at the DNC this week, Tony Goldwyn, Ana Navarro, our very own Ana Navarro, Mindy Kaling, and Kerry Washington, they will each host one night of the Democratic Convention in a roll similar to an awards show host, giving opening remarks and transitioning between speeches.Many celebrities have rallied around here in recent weeks, including my next guest. Take a look. All right, that's right. Lynda Carter, the original Wonder Woman, she endorsed Kamala Harris on the day President Biden stepped aside, posting this photo of the V.P. in front of a painting of Wonder Woman. The character, of course, has for decades represented women's strength and empowerment. Carter is campaigning hard for Harris and spoke out about the threat a Trump presidency she says would pose to women's rights during a Biden-Harris rally earlier this summer. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LYNDA CARTER, ACTRESS
utterances.sentences: The women in this room, the women in this country will never let you see the Oval Office again.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I sure hope so. Right now, I think there's a little technical difficulties that I can't see you, but I think we're OK.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I am so excited. I'm so thrilled.I had the privilege of meeting Kamala and Doug several years ago. I even had the privilege of having Kamala cook for me. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: And she is such a great cook, I can't tell you. She's so great and so charming and so wonderful.But more than that, what I have seen over these last years, I think this country was actually depressed. I think that having those years under this fear and of disruption and of hate and of misogyny has been so disruptive to our psyche, that having this breath of fresh air come rushing into us, come at this time in our lives, and then with Tim, who is just a wonderful person and so sincere, that it has really changed -- I wake up in the morning and I'm singing. I'm just so thrilled that we have competent, wonderful human beings that are for the whole country, not just half the country. I'm thrilled.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. And, Lynda, I -- yes, Lynda, I think that's what the Gen Z'ers call a vibe shift in this campaign.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: But let me ask you this, just to talk about one of the issues that we're going to be hearing about a lot this week.The DNC tonight is going to feature people who have been impacted by stricter abortion laws in this country passed by states following the overturning of Roe v. Wade. What is your sense of where that issue is shaping up and how it will potentially decide this election? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: I think, if that is the only issue, that it will be a landslide.It is absolutely a travesty that we have come into this area, this time of our lives where we have stripped half the nation of their right -- the rights to their own body. And it's that the government has no place in this decision-making process. They aren't doctors. They aren't -- most -- they are not women for the most part. And the idea of that intrusion into your life is just unimaginable. And I will do everything in my power and in my pocketbook to change that. We have seen the repercussions of it. And that's 40 percent of the United States is under these draconian mandates of anti-abortion, 40 percent of the states. That's shocking. And we have to do something about it. And I hope that we just knock every single Republican off the ticket if we can. Vote blue, vote blue, vote blue. It has nothing to do with anything that is religious. It has nothing to do with that. It has to do with overreach by government. And I'm opposed to it. ACOSTA:  Yes, and, Lynda, I mean, one of the things that we have been hearing out on the campaign trail, Donald Trump engaging in some very personal attacks aimed at Kamala Harris, criticizing her laugh and all sorts of things. (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: You're laughing right now.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Oh, God, I'm so happy to laugh again. I love her laugh. I love her dancing. I love the joy.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: How do you think she should handle all that? Yes.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right, well, Lynda Carter, I hope to see you out on the dance floor one of these days. We will cut a rug.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: Well, you take me for a spin.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: I'd love to, any time.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: Lynda Carter, thank you so much. It was such an honor for all of us. We were so excited to have you on this program. Really appreciate it. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: CARTER
utterances.sentences: And, Jim, thank you so -- Thank you so much, Jim. It's always my pleasure.
